November 1, 2009: Fiction
THE LOST SYMBOL, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $29.95.) Robert Langdon
among the Masons.
PURSUIT OF HONOR, by Vince Flynn. (Atria, $27.99.) The counterterrorism
operative Mitch Rapp must teach politicians about national security following a
new Qaeda attack.
NINE DRAGONS, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) The Los Angeles
detective Harry Bosch fights crime at home and in Hong Kong.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
THE LAST SONG, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $24.99.) A 17-year-old girl
spends the summer with her divorced father in North Carolina and finds many
kinds of love.
A TOUCH OF DEAD, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $23.95.) The complete Sookie
Stackhouse stories.
HALF BROKE HORSES, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $26.) A re-creation of the
life of the author’s grandmother, a mustang breaker, schoolteacher, ranch wife
and mother of two who grew up in the Southwest in the early 20th century, by the
author of “The Glass Castle.”
ROUGH COUNTRY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) Virgil Flowers
investigates a string of murders at a Minnesota resort for women.
AN ECHO IN THE BONE, by Diana Gabaldon. (Delacorte, $30.) The descendants
of Jamie Fraser and his wife, Claire, search for clues about their flight from North
Carolina during the Revolution; the seventh Outlander novel.
THE PROFESSIONAL, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $26.95.) Rich women are
turning up dead, and the Boston P.I. Spenser investigates.
HEAT WAVE, by Richard Castle. (Hyperion, $19.99.) An N.Y.P.D. homicide
detective investigates the death of a real estate tycoon and flirts with a magazine
journalist.
EVIDENCE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $28.) The Los Angeles
psychologist-detective Alex Delaware helps solve the grisly murder of an architect
and his companion.
DEATH TROOPERS, by Joe Schreiber. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $24.) Survivors of an
Imperial prison barge must contend with a plague and the undead aboard a Star
Destroyer; a “Star Wars” book.
November 1, 2009
Non-Fiction
HAVE A LITTLE FAITH, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $23.99.) A suburban rabbi
and a Detroit pastor teach lessons about the comfort of belief.
ARGUING WITH IDIOTS, written and edited by Glenn Beck, Kevin Balfe and
others. (Mercury Radio Arts/Threshold Editions, $29.99.) The case against big
government.
HIGHEST DUTY, by Chesley B. Sullenberger and Jeffrey Zaslow.
(Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.) The importance of preparing for the unexpected,
by the pilot-hero of Flight 1549.
TRUE COMPASS, by Edward M. Kennedy. (Twelve, $35.) The late senator’s
autobiography.
MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Harmony, $25.) A reissue of a best-selling
1988 autobiography.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed, from the author of “Blink.”
THE GREATEST SHOW ON EARTH, by Richard Dawkins. (Free Press, $30.)
Evidence for evolution; a counterattack on advocates of intelligent design.
WHERE MEN WIN GLORY, by Jon Krakauer. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The story of
Pat Tillman and the Army’s cover-up of his death by friendly fire in Afghanistan.
THE MURDER OF KING TUT, by James Patterson and Martin Dugard. (Little,
Brown, $26.99.) Investigating the Boy King’s sudden death.
THE TIME OF MY LIFE, by Patrick Swayze and Lisa Niemi. (Atria, $26.) A memoir
by the actor, who died in September, and his wife.
AMERICA FOR SALE, by Jerome R. Corsi. (Threshold, $27.) Resisting the global
New Deal, by the author of “Unfit for Command: Swift Boat Veterans Speak Out
Against John Kerry.”
HIGH ON ARRIVAL, by Mackenzie Phillips with Hilary Liftin. (Simon Spotlight
Entertainment, $25.99.) Recalling parties, drugs and a complicated relationship
with her father.
OFFICIAL BOOK CLUB SELECTION, by Kathy Griffin. (Ballantine, $25.) A
humorous memoir from the star of “My Life on the D-List.”
THE NATIONAL PARKS, by Dayton Duncan and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) A
companion to the PBS series.
HALF THE SKY, by Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn. (Knopf, $27.95.)
